Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2015 01:26AM jjski62 wrote: I believe you should trust your gut. If you think something else may be going on, go back and ask for further testing, another bone scan or an MRI, which may show changes that a bone scan does not. Six months between testing is long enough to see if something has changed. Joanne
Posts.Title: Can bone mets be missed with regular CT and bone scans? foreverhopeful GoldenGirls

Posts.Content: May 29, 2015 05:55AM - edited May 29, 2015 08:57AM by jjski62 Hi Stefanie, I too understand how you feel. I was stage 4 off the bat, and because I am not outwardly sick, I only chose to tell immediate family and closest of friends my diagnosis, asking them to keep the info confidential, as I am a private person to begin with. At this point I'm happy with that decision. It allows me to interact with people and not be viewed as the cancer patient before I absolutely have to be. It's a comforting diversion to go out and be viewed as "normal" when a lot of my days are spent obsessing over this disease. When I do need to confide, those close family members and friends arethe only people I would want to talk to anyway.
Posts.Title: Telling (or not telling) friends and family ABeautifulSunset steelrose

Posts.Content: May 19, 2015 03:52AM jjski62 wrote: You're letting it out and there's nothing wrong with that. It's a grieving process and it's a release. We all have these days and it's okay to not be okay. Take the Ativan if you need it. Whatever works for you is the best for you. It will get better. Time will lessen the grief and anxiety you're feeling. Hugs.
Posts.Title: Does it ever get easier? terrij152 slepeint

Posts.Content: May 19, 2015 01:13AM jjski62 wrote: I know I will never be "ok" with this diagnosis. I don't think we should expect to be okay and accepting. I have learned for the most part to live with this nightmare (I will never call it a journey). I think it took a good 5 months for things to calm down for me, when I wasn't consumed with unending tests, appointments, radiation, hospitalization etc. When the cancer runs became less and I started feeling better, I was able to focus more on everyday living. I asked for an antidepressant from the start and that helped. I remember reading others say it gets better with time. I found it to be true even though I thought I'd never feel that way. It's okay to have these roller coaster of emotions, but as time goes by it does get easier to cope with the diagnosis and you find yourself on the roller coaster less. (I hate the term "new normal" too - nothing normal about this!).
Posts.Title: Does it ever get easier? terrij152 slepeint

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2015 06:10AM jjski62 wrote: My mother died of stage 4 uterine cancer 20 years ago and at the time of her diagnosis they told her it was incurable but treatable like a chronic illness like diabetes. I heard the same spin at my diagnosis and I thought not a damn thing has changed in 20 years.
Posts.Title: On the subject of "Chronic Disease" RosesToeses Romansma

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2015 08:09AM - edited Jun 5, 2015 08:29AM by jjski62 Good for you! It is so important to have confidence in your team and feel that you are in the best possible hands and you are doing that. I know delays can be nerve racking, and I've experienced some myself, especially in the beginning, but things should get into a rhythm with your new health care team shortly and you will have peace of mind. I made some insurance changes at the beginning of my treatment from an HMO to a PPO because of all the extra steps I had to take with the HMO, like referrals and things. You just don't realize how important good insurance, doctors, and top notch treatment centers are until you are battling serious illness. Good luck with your treatments.  Joanne

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2015 06:01PM jjski62 wrote: Hi intothewoods, I am on the ibrance/femara combo, so this is promising news if you are getting covered with faslodex/ibrance combo.  My onc had told me that would be the next move when I am ready to move on, since faslodex combo has had such promising results.  Be sure to inquire with Pfizer regarding their discount card, as although my copay was $50 for ibrance, the discount card brought it down to a $10 copay.  Please join us on the Ibrance board and let us know how you are doing!   Joanne

Posts.Content: May 24, 2015 01:51PM jjski62 wrote: OMG Hydranne that's the best! LOL "...thai beef hold the f*cking cancer!" I know EXACTLY what you mean. I'm living this nightmare. I don't need constant reminders and pity parties. I'm relatively new to this diagnosis and since I was stage 4 off the bat, I don't look like I have f*cking cancer, and right now I have chosen to only disclose it to my immediately family and close friends for that very reason. I have no desire to explain my f*cking cancer to people I seriously could do without. I'm glad I'm not the only one and was starting to think I'ma cold hearted biotch, but it's made things easier for me right now. I'm sure when my f*cking cancer is more visible, I will react to people in much the same way as you Hydranne.
